{{otheruses}}
−
'''Ethics''' (from the [[Ancient Greek]] "''ethikos''", meaning "arising from habit") is one of the major branches of [[philosophy]], one that covers the [[Philosophical analysis|analysis]] and employment of [[concept|concepts]] such as [[right]], [[wrong]], [[good]], [[evil]], and [[responsibility]]. It is divided into three primary areas: ''meta-ethics'' (the study of what ethicality is), ''normative ethics'' (the study of what ethical truths there are and how they are known), and ''applied ethics'' (the study of the use of ethical knowledge).
+
'''Ethics''' (from the [[Ancient Greek]] "''ethikos''", meaning "arising from habit") is one of the major branches of [[philosophy]], one that covers the [[Philosophical analysis|analysis]] and employment of [[concept|concepts]] such as [[right]], [[wrong]], [[good]], [[evil]], and [[moral responsibility|responsibility]]. It is divided into three primary areas: ''meta-ethics'' (the study of what ethicality is), ''normative ethics'' (the study of what ethical truths there are and how they are known), and ''applied ethics'' (the study of the use of ethical knowledge).
     
==Meta-ethics==

Line 7: Line 7:      
===Ethical propositions and truth-aptitude===
 
===Ethical propositions and truth-aptitude===
−
One of the fundamental debates in ethics is between [[cognitivism (ethics)|cognitivists]] and [[non-cognitivism|non-cognitivists]]. Their debate is over the truth-aptitude of ethical propositions. Ethical propositions are those used to either positively or a negatively morally evaluate something. Concepts of value, e.g. good and evil, or concepts of [[deontic modality]], e.g. obligation ("should/ought") and prohibition ("should not/ought not"), or similar concepts of other kinds (e.g. fairness and unfairness), are typically components of ethical propositions. Here are some examples:
+
One of the fundamental debates in ethics is between [[cognitivism (ethics)|cognitivists]] and [[non-cognitivism|non-cognitivists]]. Their debate is over the truth-aptitude of ethical propositions. Ethical propositions are those used to either positively or a negatively morally evaluate something. Concepts of value, e.g. good and evil, or concepts of [[deontic logic|deontic modality]], e.g. obligation ("should/ought") and prohibition ("should not/ought not"), or similar concepts of other kinds (e.g. fairness and unfairness), are typically components of ethical propositions. Here are some examples:
     
* "Sally is a good person."
 
* "Sally is a good person."
